results.headline: Sixth Sense, The (Movie)
results.summary_short: What starts out as a horror movie about a troubled 8-year-old boy (Haley Joel Osment) who claims to see dead people, and the child psychologist (Bruce Willis) determined to cure him, eventually turns into New Age mush (think ''What Dreams May Come'' and ''Simon Birch''). When you trace the plot backward after its big secret is revealed, the story doesn't begin to add up. Mr. Willis gives his usual smirking one-note performance. What empathy the movie generates comes from Mr. Osment's intense portrayal of the tormented child. — Stephen Holden

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sixth Sense

results.headline: Dick (Movie)
results.summary_short: Now we know the identity of Deep Throat, the confidential source who gave the journalists Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein the inside dish about Richard Nixon's role in the Watergate scandal and helped bring down his Presidency. "Dick" reveals the snitches to have been two giggly 15-year-old girls, Betsy (Kirsten Dunst) and Arlene (Michelle Williams), whom Nixon had appointed his official dog walkers. In remembering the good old days of plumbers and White House tape recordings, this extended, wildly funny "Saturday Night Live"-style sketch spares no one. Dan Hedaya's shifty-eyed, hunch-shouldered Nixon caricature is the hilarious embodiment of paranoid guilt. — Stephen Holden

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dick

results.headline: IRON GIANT, THE (MOVIE)
results.summary_short: Based loosely on a children's fable written in 1968 by Ted Hughes, this film looks at the fearful years of the cold war through the politically correct lens of the 1990's. All this re-examination of the atmosphere of the post-Sputnik era is wrapped up in the story of a bright (and therefore unpopular) little boy who befriends a 50-foot-tall iron robot from who knows where that plunges into the sea one stormy night in 1957 and comes ashore near Rockwell, Me. The boy, Hogarth Hughes, saves the giant when it becomes entangled in high-tension wires, and the big lug becomes his secret playmate. Meanwhile, a nasty, paranoid Government agent is closing in on the giant, leading to a showdown with the military. "The Iron Giant" is a smooth, skilled example of animated filmmaking. Many parents will doubtless approve of the film's messages while they ponder how the passing years have smoothed the jagged edges of history. — Lawrence Van Gelder

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Iron Giant

results.headline: Cabaret Balkan (Movie)
results.summary_short: When one character in "Cabaret Balkan" bitterly describes Belgrade as a hemorrhoid, he isn't joking. The movie, directed by the Serbian director Goran Paskaljevic, is a "La Ronde"-like series of brutal confrontations, all taking place on the same frigid winter night in 1995 on which frustrated residents of the city humiliate and murder one another. The scenes, introduced "Cabaret"-style by a smirking, androgynous master of ceremonies, portray a society so at odds with itself it is on the verge of committing mass suicide. Powerfully acted, but brutal, depressing and deeply misanthropic, "Cabaret Balkan" is not for the squeamish. — Stephen Holden

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cabaret Balkan

results.headline: My Life So Far (Movie)
results.summary_short: A steady "Masterpiece Theater"-like glow warms "My Life So Far," a boy's reverie of growing up in the misty Scottish highlands of Argyll in the late 1920's. Frisky little Fraser (Robert Norman), who narrates the story, recalls a year in the life of the mildly troubled Macintosh clan. What strife there is mostly involves his father, Edward (Colin  Firth), an eccentric fiery-eyed inventor, and his Uncle Morris (Malcolm  McDowell), who brings home a beautiful French wife (Irene Jacob), with whom Edward falls in love. If the story is slight, it is smoothly told and well acted (especially by Mr. Firth), and the nostalgic atmosphere is beguiling. — Stephen Holden

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Life So Far
